SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 4 and 6  and Division 3.a (North Sea  Rockall and West of Scotland  kagerrak and Kattegat)
Description:
White anglerfish (Lophius piscatorius) and black anglerfish (L. budegassa) are two closely related species. White anglerfish occur throughout the north-east Atlantic. They are most abundant at depths of 200-800m but also occur in coastal waters. Black anglerfish occur from the north of Scotland to the west of Africa and are mainly found offshore between 200 and 500m depth. White anglerfish are relatively more abundant in northern areas while black anglerfish are relatively more abundant in Biscay and further south as well as an area in the western Celtic Sea. Recent research suggests that the two species occasionally inter-breed to form hybrids.

Anglerfish are difficult to age but are known to be relatively fast-growing. White anglerfish grow around 15cm per year and black anglerfish around 12cm per year. Females grow larger than males and mature at larger sizes. There is no minimum landing size but EC 2406/96 established a minimum marketing size of 500 g gutted weight or 200 g tailed.

The population structure of anglerfish is poorly understood but genetic diversity within the species appears to be limited. Anglerfish can migrate hundreds of kilometres and the eggs and larvae are pelagic for up to 4 months, allowing them to be dispersed over large areas. Recruitment success varies strongly between years.
TAC2020: The annual landings of anglerfish by Irish vessels were approximately 4,400 tonnes in the last 3 years, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal fish species: the landings in 2019 were worth around €17 million.
TAC2019: Irish anglerfish landings are around 4,300 tonnes per year, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal fish species: the landings in 2018 were worth &#8364 14,760,000.
TAC2018: Irish anglerfish landings are around 4,180 tonnes per year, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal species after Nephrops; the landings were worth nearly € 14,000,000 in 2017.
TAC2017: Irish anglerfish landings have been around 4,000 tonnes in recent years, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal species after Nephrops; the landings were worth nearly &#8364 15,000,000 in 2016.
TAC2016: Irish anglerfish landings have been around 3,800 tonnes in recent years, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal species after Nephrops; the landings were worth approximately &#8364 13,200,000 in 2015.
TAC2015: Irish anglerfish landings have been around 3,600 tonnes in recent years, mostly from 7.g and 7.j. Anglerfish are the most valuable demersal species after Nephrops; the landings were worth approximately &#8364 12,300,000 in 2014.
ICESAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2020 should be no more than 17 645 tonnes.
ICESAdvice2019: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2020 should be no more than 22056 tonnes.
ICESAdvice2018: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2019 should be no more than 31 690 tonnes.
ICESAdvice2017: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2018 should be no more than 26,408 tonnes. If discard rates do not change from the average of the last 3 years (2014-2016), this implies landings of no more than 25,563 tonnes.
ICESAdvice2016: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2017 should be no more than 22,007 t. If discard rates do not change from the average of the last three years (2013-2015), this implies landings of no more than 21,171 t.
ICESAdvice2015: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2016 should be no more than 18 435 tonnes. If discard rates do not change from the average of the last three years (2012-2014), this implies landings of no more than 17 642 tonnes.

ManagementPlan:
The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in Western Waters and adjacent waters (EU, 2019) applies to
this stock complex in Eu waters. The MAP stipulates that when the FMSY ranges are not available, fishing opportunities should be based on the best available scientific advice.
ManagementPlan2019: The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in North Sea and adjacent waters (EU, 2018) applies to this stock complex in Eu waters. The MAP stipulates that when the FMSY ranges are not available, fishing opportunities should be based on the best available scientific advice.
ManagementPlan2018: ICES is not aware of any agreed precautionary management plan for anglerfish in this area.

ICESAdvice2020:
ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2021
that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 23 320 tonnes and 45 996 tonnes. According to the MAP, catches
higher than those corresponding to FMSY (34 579 tonnes) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, whilst
the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.
Management of catches of the two anglerfish species, Lophius budegassa and L. piscatorius, under a combined species
total allowable catch (TAC) prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to the
overexploitation of either species.
ICESAdvice2019:
ICES advises that when the EU muliannual plan (MAP) for Western waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches
in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 21 428 tonnes and 42 331 tonnes. According to
the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (31 798 tonnes) can only be taken under conditions
specified in the MAP, while the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.
Management of catches of the two anglerfish species, Lophius budegassa and L. piscatorius, under a combined
species TAC prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to the overexploitation
of either species.
ICESAdvice2018: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2019 should be no more than 10 799 tonnes. Management of Lophius budegassa and L. piscatorius under a combined species TAC prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to the overexploitation of either species.
ICESAdvice2017: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, landings should be no more than 26,691 t in each of the years 2017 and 2018. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding total catches.
ICESAdvice2016: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, landings should be no more than 26,691 t in each of the years 2017 and 2018. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding total catches.
ICESAdvice2015:
ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, landings in 2016 should be no more than 10 757 tonnes. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding total catches.

Management of the two anglerfish species under a combined TAC prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to overexploitation of either species.

The recruitment index is defined by fish < 25cm. Dashed gray lines indicate &#1772 s.d. Discards are thought to occur, but no reliable estimates exist.
ManagementPlan:
The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in in the Western Waters and adjacent waters applies to
this stock. The plan specifies conditions for setting fishing opportunities, depending on stock status
and making use of the F<MSY range for the stock.
In accordance with the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding  to FMSY can only be taken
providing SSB is greater than MSY Btrigger, and one of the following conditions is met:
a) if it is necessary for the achievement of objectives of mixed fisheries;
b) if it is necessary to avoid serious harm to a stock caused by intra- or inter-species stock
dynamics;
c) in order to limit variations in fishing opportunities between consecutive years to not
more than 20%.
ICES considers that the FMSY range for this stock used in the MAP is precautionary.
ManagementPlan2019: The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in in the Western Waters and adjacent waters applies to this stock. The plan specifies conditions for setting fishing opportunities depending on stock status and making use of the FMSY range for the stock.
ManagementPlan2018: NA
FEASAdvice2020:
ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2021 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 23,320 t and 45,996 t. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to F<sub>MSY</sub> (34,579 t) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, while the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.
FEAS considers that the conditions to set the TAC above F<sub>MSY</sub> in the MAP are not met and that the catches of white anglerfish should not be more than 34,579 t.
ICES also advises that management of black and white anglerfish under a combined species TAC, prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to the overexploitation of either species.
FEASAdvice2019:
Black anglerfish (Lophius budegassa): ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches in 2020 should be no more than 12,959 t.

White anglerfish (Lophius piscatorius): ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 21,428 t and 42,331 t. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (31,798 t) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, while the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.

FEAS considers that the conditions to set the TAC above FMSY in the MAP are not met and that the catches of white anglerfish should not be more than 31,798 t.

ICES also advises that management of black and white anglerfish under a combined species TAC, prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to the overexploitation of either species.
FEASAdvice2018:
White anglerfish (Lophius piscatorius): ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2019 should be no more than 31,042 t.

ICES also advises that management of black and white anglerfish under a combined species TAC prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates and could lead to the overexploitation of either species.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 6-8 (Celtic Seas  English Channel  and Bay of Biscay)
Description:
Boarfish is a small, pelagic, plankton eating, shoaling species, found at depths of up to
600 m. The species is widely distributed from Norway to Senegal, including the
Mediterranean and oceanic island waters, but mostly south of Ireland to north Spain.
Boarfish recruit to the fishery around three to four years of age, although the
maximum age of boarfish is about 30. Spawning occurs on the Celtic Sea shelf edge
during June and July. Under optimal conditions, boarfish are capable of spawning over
an extended period of time. Maturation occurs at 3.5 years, corresponding to a total
length of approximately 10 cm. The maximum size of this species is about 18 cm.
Boarfish does not appear to be an important prey species in the Celtic Sea area.
TAC2020: On average approximately 11,640 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2017 and 2019, most of which were caught in 7.h and 8.a. Ireland dominates the international fishery, with Denmark the only other significant participant. In 2019 landings were worth approximately €2,155,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 13,650 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2016 and 2018, most of which were caught in 7.h and 8.a. Ireland dominates the international fishery, with Denmark the only other significant participant. In 2018 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,483,900 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 16,000 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2015 and 2017, most of which were caught in 7.h and 8.a. Ireland dominates the international fishery, with Denmark the only other significant participant. In 2017 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2,320,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 22,800 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2014 and 2016, most of which were caught in 7.j and 7.h. Ireland dominates the international fishery, with Denmark the only other significant participant. In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 34,400 tonnes of boarfish were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2013 and 2015,  most of which were caught in 7.j and 7.h Irelands dominates the international fishery, with Denmark the only other significant participant. In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,875,832 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: On average approximately 1,700 tonnes of cod annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014. In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 3,254,900 for Irish vessels.

ICESAdvice2019: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, catches should be no more than 19 152 tonnes in each of the years 2020 and 2021.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.e-k (eastern English Channel and southern Celtic Seas)
Description: Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) are widely distributed on both sides of the north Atlantic. In the NE Atlantic they occur from Norway to the Bay of Biscay. Cod around Ireland are very fast growing and attain lengths in excess of 35cm in the first year and over 90cm as adults. About 50% of individuals are mature at 2 years and virtually 100% are mature by 3 years of age. Juveniles are more commonly found from 30 to 80 m, mainly on rocky bottoms. Their diet consists of benthic animals, crustaceans and small fish. Fish become more prevalent in the diet in older cod. Once mature an adult female can produce over 2 million eggs.
TAC2020: On average approximately 787 tonnes of cod were caught and landed annually in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019, greater than 61% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2019 landings were worth approximately €2.5 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 878 tonnes of cod were caught and landed annually in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, greater than 64% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2018 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2,540,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 1,000 tonnes of cod were caught and landed annually in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, greater than 60% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2017 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 1,300 tonnes of cod annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2016, 65% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2,200,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 1,355 tonnes of cod annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 64% of which were caught in 7.g. In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 3,690,510 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: On average approximately 1,700 tonnes of cod annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014. In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 3,254,900 for Irish vessels.

ICESAdvice2019: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catch in 2020.
ICESAdvice2018: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catch in 2019.
ICESAdvice2017: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2018 should be no more than 3,428 t. If discard rates do not change from the average of the last 3 years (2014-2016), this implies landings of no more than 3,076 t.
ICESAdvice2016: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, wanted catch in 2017 should be no more than 1,447 t. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding total catches.
ICESAdvice2015: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, wanted catch  in 2016 should be no more than 3569 tonnes. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding total catches because of variable discard rates in the recent past.

ManagementPlan:
The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in the Western Waters and adjacent waters applies to this stock. The plan specifies conditions for setting fishing opportunities depending on stock status, and for making use of the FMSY range for the stock.

Full details of the plan are described in EU (2019).
ManagementPlan2019: The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in in the Western Waters and adjacent waters applies to this stock. The plan specifies conditions for setting fishing opportunities depending on stock status and making use of the FMSY range for the stock.
ManagementPlan2018: ICES is not aware of any agreed precautionary management plan for cod in this area.

ManagementPlan: At the 46th meeting of the Joint Russian-Norwegian Fisheries Commission (JRNFC) in October 2016, the previously used management plan was amended, and the current plan is as follows: The TAC is calculated as the average catch predicted for the coming 3 years, using the target level of exploitation (Ftr). The target level of exploitation is calculated according to the spawning-stock biomass (SSB) in the first year of the forecast as follows: - if SSB < Bpa, then Ftr = SSB / Bpa x FMSY; - if Bpa <= SSB <= 2 x Bpa, then Ftr = FMSY; - if 2 x Bpa < SSB < 3 x Bpa, then Ftr = FMSY x (1 + 0.5 x (SSB - 2 x Bpa) / Bpa); - if SSB >= 3 x Bpa, then Ftr = 1.5 x FMSY; where FMSY = 0.40 and Bpa = 460 000 tonnes. If the spawning-stock biomass in the present year, the previous year, and each of the three years of prediction is above Bpa, the TAC should not be changed by more than ±20% compared with the previous year's TAC. In this case, Ftr should however not be below 0.30. In 2014, JNRFC decided that from 2015 onwards, Norway and Russia can transfer to or borrow from the following year up to 10% of the country's quota. Advice ICES evaluated this harvest control rule in 2016 (ICES, 2016) and concluded that it is precautionary.

ManagementPlan:
The European Parliament and the Council have published a multiannual management plan (MAP) for the Western Waters (EU, 2019). This plan applies to demersal stocks including cod in ICES Division 7.a.
The MAP stipulates that when the FMSY ranges are not available the precautionary approach should be
applied.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 1-9  12  and 14 (Northeast Atlantic and adjacent waters)
Description: Blue whiting is a small, pelagic, densely-shoaling gadoid. It is widely distributed in the eastern north Atlantic from Norway to Portugal. They recruit to the fishery from one year of age, although the maximum age is about 15. The population is comprised of at least a northern and a southern component, both spawning mainly between 300 and 600 m along the continental margin off Ireland and Scotland. Juveniles are widely distributed, including in the Bay of Biscay and Iberian waters, with the main nursery area believed to be in the Norwegian Sea. Maturation occurs at 2.5 years, corresponding to a total length of approximately 23 cm. The maximum size of this species is about 38 cm. Blue whiting is an important prey species.
TAC2020: On average approximately 43,900 tonnes of blue whiting were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2017 and 2019, 62% of which were caught in sub-area 6.a. Norway dominates the international fishery, with the Faroes, Iceland, UK, Ireland and Russia also significant participants. In 2019 the landings were worth approximately €7,940,000 to Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 39,893 tonnes of blue whiting were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2016 and 2018, 61% of which were caught in 7.c. Norway dominates the international fishery, with the Faroes, Iceland, UK, Ireland and Russia also significant participants. In 2018 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,434,500 to Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 32,900 tonnes of blue whiting were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2015 and 2017, 56% of which were caught in 7.c. Norway dominates the international fishery, with the Faroes, Iceland, UK, Ireland and Russia also significant participants. In 2017 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 7 million to Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 24,637 tonnes of blue whiting were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2014 and 2016, 56% of which were caught in 7.c. Norway dominates the international fishery, with the Faroes, Iceland, UK, Ireland and Russia also significant participants. In 2016 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 6,300,000 to Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 19,800 tonnes of blue whiting were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2013 and 2015, 43% of which were caught in 7.c. Norway dominates the international fishery, with the Faroes, Iceland, UK, Ireland and Russia also significant participants. In 2015 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 10,112,384 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: On average approximately 14,000 tonnes of blue whiting were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2012 and 2014. Norway dominates the international fishery, with the Faroes, Iceland, UK, Ireland and Russia also significant participants. In 2014 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,838,750 for Irish vessels.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.b -c and 7.e-k (southern Celtic Seas and eastern English Channel)
Description:
Whiting are widely distributed throughout Irish and European waters from the shallows down to depths of around 200m.  Adults are found over sandy/muddy ground. Juveniles are most abundant in coastal waters. 
Whiting are voracious feeders appearing in large shoals and feeding largely on
crustaceans and small fish. Their fine sharp teeth reflect their
predatory diet; hunting mobile prey in the water column. They are fast growing and can grow up to 20cm in their first year at which stage about 60% are sexually mature.  At
age 2 almost 100% of females and ~ 85% of males are fully mature.
TAC2020: On average approximately 4,700 tonnes of whiting were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019, 69% of these were caught in 7g. In 2019 landings were worth approximately €4,275,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 6,360 tonnes of whiting were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, 78% of these were caught in 7g. In 2018 landings were worth approximately &#8364 6,797,200 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 6,971 tonnes of whiting were caught annually and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, 78% of which were caught in 7g. Ireland's share in Sub-areas 7b-k is the second most valuable whiting TAC. In 2017 landings were worth approximately &#8364 8,757,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 7,156 tonnes of whiting were caught annually and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, 76% of which were caught in 7g. Ireland's share in Sub-areas 7b-k is the second most valuable whiting TAC. In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,800,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 6,400 tonnes of whiting were caught annually and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 70% of which were caught in VIIg. Irelands share in Sub-areas VIIb-k is the second most valuable whiting TAC. In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 8,050,903 for Irish vessels
TAC2015: On average approximately 6,400 tonnes of whiting were caught annually and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014. Irelands share in Sub-areas VIIb-k is the second most valuable whiting TAC. In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 8,050,903 for Irish vessels

FEASAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catches in 2021. Advice for this stock is issued biennially and there was no new advice this year. In response to an EC request ICES provided a technical service on unavoidable by-catches which states "forecasted bycatch levels in 2021 are 930 t, using a model of whiting bycatch in the Nephrops fishery and assuming 7,300 t of Nephrops catches in 2021. This is expected to result in a 7% increase in SSB of whiting in 2022".
FEASAdvice2019: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catches in 2020 and 2021.
FEASAdvice2018:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catches in 2019.

In response to an EC request for advice on the removal of TACs for certain stocks ICES advises that removing the EU TAC for Whiting in ICES Division 7.a may generate a high risk of the stock being unsustainably exploited. However, ICES notes that the TAC is not currently controlling exploitation.

ManagementPlan:
An EU multiannual management plan (MAP) has been agreed by the EU for this stock (EU, 2018).
There is no agreement with Norway regarding this plan and it is not used as the basis of the advice for this shared stock. ICES was requested by the EC to provide advice based on the MSY approach, and to include the MAP as a catch option. EU-Norway have requested an evaluation of multiple management strategies (ICES, 2019a), which are currently under consideration.

StockDev2015: Haddock in Division VIb. Summary of stock assessment (weights in thousand tonnes).
ManagementPlan:
There is no agreed management plan for haddock in this area. Two management strategies (NEAFC and EU MAP) have been assessed to be precautionary. NEAFC has requested ICES to evaluate the harvest control rules using FMSY as target. ICES concluded that the NEAFC harvest control rules in the long-term
management strategy for Rockall haddock were consistent with the precautionary approach (ICES, 2019a).
The EU multi-annual plan (MAP) for stocks in in the Western Waters and adjacent waters applies to this
stock. The plan specifies conditions for seeing fishing opportunities depending on stock status and making use of the FMSY range for the stock.
In accordance with the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY can only be taken providing SSB is greater than MSY Btrigger, and one of the following conditions is met:
a) if it is necessary for the achievement of objectives of mixed fisheries;
b) if is necessary to avoid serious harm to a stock caused by intra- or inter-species stock dynamics;
c) in order to limit variations in fishing opportunities between consecutive years to not more than 20%.
ICES considers that the FMSY range for this stock used in the MAP is precautionary.
Full details of the plan are described in EU (2019a).
ManagementPlan2019: There is no agreed management plan for haddock in this area. Two management strategies (NEAFC and EU MAP) have been assessed to be precautionary.
ManagementPlan2018: There is no agreed management plan for haddock in this area. A management strategy is under consideration and not yet adopted. The strategy was evaluated by ICES in 2013 (ICES, 2013). ICES concluded that a maximum F value of 0.2 in the harvest control rule was required to ensure consistency with the precautionary approach under low recruitment conditions.

FEASAdvice2018: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2019 should be no more than 10,469 t.

Description: A pelagic schooling fish that are found in mid water or close to the bottom. Herring migrate to distant feeding grounds and are often found in mixed aggregations with other herring stocks. Their diet consists largely of zooplankton, mainly copepods. Fish reach a total length of between 28 and 37 cm, depending on the stock. Herring are important prey for marine mammals, birds and many predatory fish. Unusually for a marine fish, eggs are deposited on the bottom in discrete gravel beds. Herring eggs are also consumed by some gadoid species. In the waters around Ireland the main spawning grounds for herring are off the Donegal and Mayo coasts, and inshore along the south and west coast including Dunmore East and Cork Harbour. Herring reach full maturity by ages 2 or 3. They are not particularly fecund compared to other pelagic fish
TAC2020: On average approximately 11,500 tonnes of herring were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls annually between 2017 and 2019. Ireland dominates the fishery in 6.aS and in the Celtic Sea. In 2019 landings were worth approximately €1,987,280 to Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 15,467 tonnes of herring were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls annually between 2016 and 2018, 50% of which were caught in 7.g.  Ireland dominates the fishery in 6.aS and in the Celtic Sea. In 2018 landings were worth approximately &#8364 3,253,600 to Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 18,578 tonnes of herring were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls annually between 2015 and 2017, 63% of which were caught in 7.g.  Ireland dominates the fishery in 6.aS and in the Celtic Sea. In 2017 landings were worth approximately &#8364 5,569,000 to Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 20,883 tonnes of herring were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls annually between 2014 and 2016, 66% of which were caught in 7.g.  Ireland dominates the fishery in 6.aS and in the Celtic Sea. In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 10,000,000 to Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 22,186 tonnes of herring were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2013 and 2015, 63% of which were caught in 7.g. Irelands dominates the fishery in 6.aS and in the Celtic Sea. The Irish share of the fishery in 2.a is miniscule. In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 7,187,600 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: On average approximately 25,000 tonnes of herring were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2012 and 2014, most of which were caught in 7.g. Irelands dominates the fishery in 6.aS and in the Celtic Sea. The Irish share of the fishery in 2.a is miniscule. In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 7,300,000 for Irish vessels.

stock recovery plan is implemented for these combined stocks.
ICESAdvice2017:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catch in 2018. ICES advises that a stock recovery plan be developed for this stock.

ManagementPlan: The long-term management strategy for Celtic Sea herring that was proposed by the Pelagic AC in 2011 (Pelagic AC, 2011) was re-evaluated by ICES in 2018. ICES advises that the harvest control rule is no longer consistent with the precautionary approach. The management strategy results in a greater than 5% probability of the stock falling below Blim in several years throughout the 20-year simulated period (ICES, 2018a).
ManagementPlan2019: No
ManagementPlan2018: The long-term management strategy for Celtic Sea herring that was proposed by the Pelagic AC in 2011 (Pelagic AC, 2011) was evaluated by ICES and found to be precautionary (ICES, 2012; 2015a). ICES is requested by the EC to provide advice based on the MSY approach and to include the management strategy as a catch option.
FEASAdvice2020:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catch in 2021.
In 2019, ICES have stated that management of "this stock should be considered as part of a metapopulation. The consequence of this needs to be further evaluated for management and advice." This statement is still valid but does not appear in the 2020 abbreviated advice. FEAS notes that further work is required to quantify the mixing between Celtic Sea and Irish Sea herring stocks in the Irish Sea.
FEASAdvice2019:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be zero catch in 2020. ICES have stated that management of "this stock should be considered as part of a metapopulation. The consequence of this needs to be further evaluated for management and advice."

In particular, FEAS advises that further work is required to account for the presence of Celtic Sea herring in the Irish Sea.
FEASAdvice2018:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2019 should be no more than 4,742 t.

ICES has stated in the Irish Sea herring advice "Management of this stock [Irish Sea herring] should be considered as part of a metapopulation. The consequence of this needs to be further evaluated for management and advice." In particular, FEAS advises that further work is required to account for the presence of Celtic Sea herring in the Irish Sea.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 4  6  and 7  and Divisions 3.a  8.a-b  and 8.d  Northern stock (Greater North Sea  Celtic Seas  and the northern Bay of Biscay)
Description:
Hake are widely distributed throughout the north-east Atlantic, mostly between 50
and 700m depth. Adult hake mainly feed on fish and squid and can occur close to
the bottom as well as off the bottom. Hake are relatively fast growing (around 15cm
per year in the first few years of life). Males mature around 35cm and females
around 50cm. The spawning period is long and occurs mostly in the first 6 months
of the year.
There is no evidence for the existence of multiple populations of hake in the northeast
Atlantic, so from a biological point of view this is considered to be a single
stock.
TAC2020: On average approximately 3,557 tonnes of hake were landed annually by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019, most of which were caught in 7.g and 7.j. In 2019 landings were worth approximately €11,207,000 for Irish vessels.

ManagementPlan:
The EU multiannual plan (MAP) for stocks in the Western Waters and adjacent has been agreed by the 
EU for this stock (EU, 2019). This plan is not adopted by Norway; thus, it was not used as the basis of 
the advice for this shared stock. ICES was requested to provide advice based on the MSY approach and 
to include the MAP as a catch option.

SpeciesByDiv: Subarea 8 and Divisions 2.a  4.a  5.b  6.a  7.a-c e-k (the Northeast Atlantic)
Description:
Horse mackerel is a widely-distributed pelagic species, sometimes regarded as semipelagic
as they are often found near the seabed. They are a relatively long lived
species that can live for more than 26 years. Large fluctuations in year class strength
are a feature of horse mackerel stocks. Maturity is reached between the ages of 2 and
4. The western stock spawns in the Celtic Sea in June, followed by a northerly feeding
migration. The stock may enter the North Sea from the north with abundance
associated with the influx of Atlantic water. The return migration takes place in late
autumn. Juveniles are pelagic feeders while larger individuals feed closer to the bottom,
mainly on 0-group fish.

TAC2017: On average, 27,000 tonnes of horse mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, mainly from subareas 6.a and 7.b. In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 15,000,000 for Irish vessels.

TAC2015: On average, 38,000 tonnes of horse mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014. Catches are mainly from subareas 6.a, 7.b and 7.j. In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 19.5 million for  Irish vessels.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.b-k  8.a-b  and 8.d (west and southwest of Ireland  Bay of Biscay)
Description:
Megrim (Lepidorhombus whiffiagonis) and four-spot megrim (L. boscii) are two closely related flatfish species. L. whiffiagonis occurs throughout the north-east Atlantic while L. boscii occurs from the Mediterranean up to the Faroe Islands. Both species occur from inshore waters up to depths of around 800m but L. whiffiagonis are most abundant around 100-300m while L. boscii are most abundant around 200-600m. Irish landings are nearly exclusively L. whiffiagonis.

Adult megrim feed on small demersal fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. Megrim are relatively slow growing and long-lived. They spawn around January-March. Females grow larger, mature later and live longer than males. Females mature around 22cm; the minimum conservation reference size is 20cm.
TAC2020: Approximately 3,100 tonnes of megrim are landed per year by Irish vessels operating in a mixed demersal fishery. Most of the catches originate from area 7.g. In 2019 the landings were worth close to 10 million euros for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: Approximately 3,153 tonnes of megrim are landed per year by Irish vessels operating in a mixed demersal fishery. Most of the catches originate from area 7.g. In 2018 the landings were worth more than &#8364 9,170,700 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: Approximately 3,165 tonnes of megrim are landed per year by Irish vessels operating in a mixed demersal fishery. Most of the catches originate from area 7.g. In 2017 the landings were worth more than &#8364 10,345,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of megrim are caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, most of which were caught in 7.g. In 2016 the landings were worth more than &#8364 10,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of megrim are caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, most of which were caught in 7.g. In 2015 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,600,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of megrim are caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014, most of which were caught in 7.g. In 2014 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 8,500,000 for Irish vessels.
ICESAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2021 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 12 706 tonnes and 27 748 tonnes. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (19 184 tonnes) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, whilst the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule. Management of catches of the two megrim species, L. whiffiagonis and L. boscii, under a combined species TAC prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates, and could lead to overexploitation of either species.
ICESAdvice2019:
ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 13 218 tonnes and 28 838 tonnes. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (19 982 tonnes) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, while the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.

Management of catches of the two megrim species, L. whiffiagonis and L. boscii, under a combined species TAC prevents effective control of the single-species exploitation rates, and could lead to overexploitation of either species.
ICESAdvice2018:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2019 should be no more than 18 976 tonnes.
Management of megrim and four-spot megrim under a combined species TAC prevents effective control of the singlespecies
exploitation rates and could lead to overexploitation of either species.
ICESAdvice2017: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2018 should be no more than 15,720 t. If discard rates do not change from the average of the last three years (2014-2016), this implies landings of no more than 12,844 t.
ICESAdvice2016: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, catches in 2017 should be no more than 16,021 t. If discard rates do not change from the average of the last three years (2013-2015), this implies landings of no more than 13,709 t.
ICESAdvice2015: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, landings in 2016 should be no more than 18 216 tonnes. ICES cannot quantify the corresponding catches.

SpeciesByDiv: Division 6.b (Rockall)
Description:
Megrim (Lepidorhombus whiffiagonis) and four-spot megrim (L. boscii) are two closely related flatfish species. L. whiffiagonis occurs throughout the north-east Atlantic while L. boscii occurs from the Mediterranean up to the Faroe Islands. Both species occur from inshore waters up to depths of around 800m but L. whiffiagonis are most abundant around 100-300m while L. boscii are most abundant around 200-600m. Irish landings are nearly exclusively L. whiffiagonis.

Adult megrim feed on small demersal fish, cephalopods and crustaceans. Megrim are relatively slow growing and long-lived. Megrim spawn around January-March. Females grow larger, mature later and live longer than males. Females mature around 22cm; the minimum conservation reference size is 20cm (which is the same as the historic landing size).
TAC2020: Approximately 3,100 tonnes of megrim are landed per year by Irish vessels operating in a mixed demersal fishery. Most of the catches originate from area 7.g. In 2019 the landings were worth close to 10 million euros for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: Approximately 3,153 tonnes of megrim are landed per year by Irish vessels operating in a mixed demersal fishery. Most of the catches originate from area 7.g. In 2018 the landings were worth more than &#8364 9,170,700 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: Approximately 3,165 tonnes of megrim are landed per year by Irish vessels operating in a mixed demersal fishery. Most of the catches originate from area 7.g. In 2017 the landings were worth more than &#8364 10,345,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of megrim are caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, most of which were caught in 7.g. In 2016 the landings were worth more than &#8364 10,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of megrim are caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, most of which were caught in 7.g. In 2015 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,600,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: Approximately 3,000 tonnes of megrim are caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014, most of which were caught in 7.g. In 2014 the landings were worth approximately &#8364 8,500,000 for Irish vessels.

SpeciesByDiv: Division 7.a (Irish Sea)
Description:
Black sole (also called Dover sole) are flat fish which lie buried on sandy or muddy seabed. They feed primarily at night on small crustaceans, worms and bivalve molluscs. In common with many flatfish, sole are fast growing as juveniles, slowing down as they mature. Females grow larger than the males. They can reach lengths of up to 70cm or weights of up to 3kg. Sole are quite solitary marine and estuarine fish, and the local environment may contribute to variable growth rates.

Females reach maturity at around 3 years when they are around 25-30cm long. An average mature female can produce in the region of 150,000 - 200,000 eggs a year. They spawn in spring and early summer.Juveniles (<3 years) are found in coastal nurseries before they move in to deeper waters.
TAC2020: The annual landings of sole by Irish vessels were approximately 165 tonnes in the last 3 years, 47% of which were caught in 7.j. In 2019 landings were worth around €2.1 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 185 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, 50% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2018 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,470,600 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 197 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, 48% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2017 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,631,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 198 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, 45% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 193 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 41% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,752,964 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: On average approximately 205 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014.  In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,715,000 for Irish vessels.

ICESAdvice2015: ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, there should be no directed fisheries and all catches should be minimized in 2016.

Recruitment (R) has been variable; the 2017 and 2019 estimates are among the highest in the time-series.

FEASAdvice2019:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied using the assessment conducted in spring 2019, which incorporates the 2019 inter-benchmark settings, catches in 2019 should be no more than 1,488 t.

ICES notes that the advice provided in June 2019 for 2020 for this stock assumed that catches in 2019 would be equal to the established TAC for 2019 of 841 t. ICES advises that if the TAC for 2019 is revised, the advice for 2020 from June 2019 would no longer be valid. Depending on the scenario retained, the corresponding advice for 2020 would be as follows:

a) If the TAC for 2019 is revised to 1,488 t (fishing at FMSY in 2019), ICES advises that catches in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 918 t and 2,402 t. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (1,559 t) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, while the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.

b) If the TAC for 2019 is revised to 1,009 t (the management scenario assumed for 2019 in the request, and equivalent to the 2019 TAC +20%), ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 993 t and 2,597 t. According to the MAP, catches higher than those corresponding to FMSY (1,686 t) can only be taken under conditions specified in the MAP, while the entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.
FEASAdvice2018: The ICES advice, based on the MSY approach, is that catches in 2019 should be no more than 864 t.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 6, 12, 14 and Division 5.b (West of Scotland and Rockall Sole)
Description:
Black sole (also called Dover sole) are flat fish which lie buried on sandy or muddy seabed. They feed primarily at night on small crustaceans, worms and bivalve molluscs. In common with many flatfish, sole are fast growing as juveniles, slowing down as they mature. Females grow larger than the males. They can reach lengths of up to 70cm or weights of up to 3kg. Sole are quite solitary marine and estuarine fish, and the local environment may contribute to variable growth rates.

Females reach maturity at around 3 years when they are around 25-30cm long. An average mature female can produce in the region of 150,000 - 200,000 eggs a year. They spawn in spring and early summer.Juveniles (<3 years) are found in coastal nurseries before they move in to deeper waters.
TAC2020: The annual landings of sole by Irish vessels were approximately 165 tonnes in the last 3 years, 47% of which were caught in 7.j. In 2019 landings were worth around €2.1 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 185 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, 50% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2018 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,470,600 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 197 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, 48% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2017 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,631,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 198 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, 45% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2016 landings were worth approximately &#8364 2,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: On average approximately 193 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 41% of which were caught in 7.j.  In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,752,964 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: On average approximately 205 tonnes of sole annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014.  In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 1,715,000 for Irish vessels.

This stock will not be subject to the Landing Obligation in 2016.

Landings reached a peak of around 110 t in the late nineties, with rapid decline since then to the present value of 19.5 t for 2013.  The combination of technical measures (Council Regulation 43/2009) and effort reduction are expected to have significantly reduced mortality on sole in Division VIa. 

There is no management plan in place for this stock.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 1-8 and 14 and Division 9.a (the Northeast Atlantic and adjacent waters)
Description:
The Atlantic Mackerel is a widely distributed, migratory pelagic fish that inhabits
much of the north-eastern Atlantic shelf. It is streamlined and fast swimming,
forming dense shoals when migrating to spawning grounds to the south and west
of Ireland. Spawning takes place between February and July after which they
migrate north, disperse and feed. Diet depends on season but consists mainly of
zooplankton and juvenile fish. Juvenile mackerel grow rapidly and reach 30cm
after 2 years at which point more than half are mature. The majority of mackerel
caught are between 4 and 8 years of age with individuals older than 15 rare.
TAC2020: On average, approximately 68,500 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a, 6.a and 7.b. It is the most valuable pelagic stock to Ireland worth approximately €71 million euros in 2019. Ireland has approximately 17% of the overall EU TAC.
TAC2019: On average, approximately 75,300 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a and 6.a. It is the most valuable pelagic stock to Ireland worth approximately &#8364 51,770,000 in 2018. Ireland has approximately 17% of the overall EU TAC.
TAC2018: On average, approximately 82,600 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a and 6.a. It is the most valuable pelagic stock to Ireland worth approximately &#8364 59,000,000 in 2017. Ireland has approximately 17% of the overall EU TAC.
TAC2017: On average, approximately 89 000 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a and 6.a. It is the most valuable pelagic stock to Ireland worth approximately &#8364 50,000,000 annually. Ireland has approximately 17% of the overall EU TAC.
TAC2016: On average, approximately 78 000 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2015, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a and 6.a. It is the most valuable stock to Ireland worth approximately 65 million euro annually. Ireland has approximately 17% of the overall EU TAC.
TAC2015: On average, approximately 74,000 tonnes of mackerel were caught and landed by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014, primarily from ICES divisions 4.a and 6.a.   In 2014 landings were worth approximately &#8364 78million for Irish vessels.

ManagementPlan: There is no long-term management strategy for Northeast Atlantic (NEA) mackerel agreed by all parties involved in the mackerel fishery. In 2019 Coastal State delegations from Norway, the EU, and the Faroes requested ICES to review new harvest control rule (HCR) options for a management strategy. ICES delivered the advice from this evaluation in August 2020 (ICES, 2020a).
ManagementPlan2019: There is no long-term management strategy for Northeast Atlantic (NEA) mackerel agreed by all parties involved in the mackerel fishery. Coastal State Delegations from Norway, the EU, and the Faroes have agreed on an arrangement for a long-term management strategy for mackerel (Anon., 2017).
ManagementPlan2018: There is no long-term management strategy for Northeast Atlantic (NEA) mackerel agreed by all parties involved in the mackerel fishery. ICES has now evaluated options for the potential management of this fishery, based on a request from Norway, the EU and the Faroe Islands (ICES, 2017b).

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.b-c (West of Ireland)
Description:
Plaice (Pleuronectes platessa) are found throughout the Atlantic coast of Europe and in the western Mediterranean. They are usually found in waters less than 100m depth. Older fish are found in deeper water. Plaice are most commonly found on sandy, muddy or gravel bottom. Small fish are found in intertidal areas and there is evidence to suggest homing behaviour.

The Irish Sea is an important spawning ground for plaice. Spawning occurs off the bottom from February to April in the Irish Sea and is dependent on water temperature. Males reach maturity between 2 and 6 years, and females between 3 and 7 years, with age at maturity again being dependent on water temperature. Young plaice feed on small worms and shrimp. As they grow their diet becomes more varied and they eat small crustaceans, crabs, mussels, scallops and shrimp.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7h-k (Celtic Sea South  southwest of Ireland)
Description:
Plaice (Pleuronectes platessa) are found throughout the Atlantic coast of Europe and in the western Mediterranean. They are usually found in waters less than 100m depth. Older fish are found in deeper water. Plaice are most commonly found on sandy, muddy or gravel bottom. Small fish are found in intertidal areas and there is evidence to suggest homing behaviour.

The Irish Sea is an important spawning ground for plaice. Spawning occurs off the bottom from February to April in the Irish Sea and is dependent on water temperature. Males reach maturity between 2 and 6 years, and females between 3 and 7 years, with age at maturity again being dependent on water temperature. Young plaice feed on small worms and shrimp. As they grow their diet becomes more varied and they eat small crustaceans, crabs, mussels, scallops and shrimp.

There is no management plan in place for this stock.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 4  6 and Division 3.a (North Sea  Rockall and West of Scotland  Skagerrak and Kattegat)
Description:
Saithe is a large Gadoid, reaching maximum size of 130cm. It is a cold-water species distributed throughout the northern Atlantic. Saithe live in shoals and occur close to the bottom, in midwater and even near the surface. Juveniles occur mostly in coastal waters while older fish move to deeper waters. Tagging experiments have shown that adults can migrate over considerable distances, indicating at least some exchange between the Norwegian coast, Faroe and Iceland. Survey data show that density in the north eastern North Sea is markedly higher during summer than during winter, suggesting dispersal during the feeding season.

Saithe feed primarily on pelagic organisms. Krill is the most important food for young fish, but is also consumed by larger individuals. Larger fish mainly feed on capelin, sandeels and other fish species. Growth is quite rapid and the saithe reach sexual maturity at the age of 5 or 6 years. The minimum conservation reference size is 35cm.
TAC2020: Landings of saithe have declined in recent years with 276 t caught in 2019 which was worth approximately €320,000 for Irish vessels.  Saithe are mainly caught in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels. Between 2017 and 2019 35% were caught in 7.g and 27% were caught in 7.j.
TAC2019: On average approximately 772 tonnes of saithe annualy were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018. 40% of which were caught in 7.g and 26% caught in 7.j. In 2018, 601 tonnes of saithe were landed which were worth approximately &#8364 672,700 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 820 tonnes of saithe annualy were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017. 42% of which were caught in 7.g and 28% caught in 7.j. In 2017, 787 tonnes of saithe were landed which were worth approximately &#8364 1,002,250 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: In 2016, 909 tonnes of Saithe were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels. Most of these landings were from 7.g and 7.j. The Irish landings in 2016 were worth approximately &#8364 1,200,000.
TAC2016: In 2015, 735 tonnes of Saithe were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels. Most of these landings were from VIIg and VIIj. The Irish landings in 2015 were worth approximately &#8364 900,000.
TAC2015: In 2014, 1,300 tonnes of Saithe were landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels. Most of these landings were from VIIg and VIIj. The Irish landings in 2014 were worth approximately &#8364 1,380,000.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 6-7 (Celtic Seas and the English Channel)
Description:
Pollack is a benthopelagic gadoid, occuring thoughout the north-east Atlantic, mainly over hard/rocky bottom. Pollack usually occur at 40-100m depth but are found down to 200m. Young pollack occur mostly inshore while older fish move to deeper waters.

Pollack are fast growing at 10cm or more per year. The maximum reported size is 130cm in length and 18.1 kg in weight. The maximum reported age is 15 years. The minimum conservation reference size is 30cm. 

Males mature at smaller sizes than females, recent studies suggest that females in the Celtic Sea mature at around 60cm in length. Spawning occurs mainly in the first half of the year, at about 100 m depth. Pollack can form dense shoals during spawning time.
TAC2020: On average approximately 800 tonnes of pollack annually were caught and landed in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019. 43% of which were caught in 7.g and 41% caught in 7.j. In 2019, 645 tonnes were landed which were worth approximately €1.6 million for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 958 tonnes of pollack annually were caught and landed  in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018. 45% of which were caught in 7.g and 39% caught in 7.j. In 2018, 776 tonnes were landed which were worth approximately &#8364 1,786,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 1,075 tonnes of pollack annually were caught and landed  in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017. 49% of which were caught in 7.g and 37% caught in 7.j. In 2017, 922 tonnes were landed which were worth approximately &#8364 1,900,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: Approximately 1,066 tonnes of pollack were caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016. In 2016, 979 tonnes were landed which were worth approximately &#8364 1,800,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2016: Approximately 1,000 tonnes of pollack were caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 53% of which were caught in VIIg. In 2015, 866 tonnes were landed which were worth approximately &#8364 1,800,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2015: Approximately 986 tonnes of pollack were caught and landed each year in mixed demersal fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014. The Irish landings in 2014 were worth approximately &#8364 1,550,000.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 6-9  12  and 14  and Divisions 3.a and 4.a (Northeast Atlantic and Arctic Ocean)
Description: An elongated member of the cod family, ling are found from 10 to 100m with adults more commonly found at depths of 100 to 400m.  They tend to be solitary fish found in rocky areas, under overhangs and around ship wrecks.  Ling spawn offshore, with major spawning grounds from 200m depth off the Bay of Biscay, slopes west of the British Isles, 100 to 300 m depth off southern Iceland and off the Faeroes to the Gulf of Norway.  Females release 20 to 60 million eggs which, along with the larvae are planktonic.  Ling feed on other fish (cod, herring, flatfish), lobsters, cephalopods and starfishes.
TAC2020: Irish vessels landed 483t of ling in 2018 and provisional figures for 2019 show landings of 452t. The Irish TAC for 2020 is 898t.

In response to an EC request for advice on the removal of TACs for certain stocks ICES advises that removing the EU TAC for ling in ICES divisions 3.a and Sub-area 4 may generate a high risk of the stocks being exploited unsustainably.

In response to an EC request for advice on the removal of TACs for certain stocks ICES advises that removing the EU TAC for ling in ICES divisions 5.b may generate a high risk of the stocks being exploited unsustainably. ICES furthermore advises that the TAC for ling in EU and international waters of Sub-area 5 can be joined to that for ling in sub-areas 6 - 9, 12, and 14, and in divisions 3.a and 4.a.

SpeciesByDiv: Division 7.a  Functional Unit 14 (Irish Sea  East)
Description:
Nephrops norvegicus is widely distributed on muddy substrates throughout the north-east Atlantic from Iceland in the north to Morocco in the south. Around Ireland they are found in depths from 20m to 600m but mainly at average depths of ~100 m on the shelf. They construct shallow burrows in muddy sediments which limits the distribution. Nephrops larvae hatch late spring/early summer. The females leave the burrows to hatch the eggs and mate. The eggs take about 4-8 weeks to develop into juveniles depending on water temperature. For the remainder of the year mature females then spend the majority of time in their burrows first to spawn the eggs and then incubate them. Male Nephrops are more active outside of the burrows foraging for food.

Unlike fish, there is no direct way to age Nephrops. Growth rates vary considerably in different areas. Mean size is negatively correlated with density of individuals. The maximum carapace length recorded for Nephrops is a male of 9.3 cm from the Porcupine Bank Irish sampling programme.
TAC2020: On average approximately 7,800 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019. FU20-21 accounted for the highest percentage of landings (27%) in 2019. In 2019 landings were worth more than 󌍩,400,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 8,300 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, 31% of which were caught in FU22.  In 2018 landings were worth more than &#8364 56,200,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, 31% of which were caught in FU22. In 2017 landings were worth more than € 56,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, 29% of which were caught in FU22. In 2016 landings were worth approximately € 60,000,000 making it Ireland's most valuable species for the first time.
TAC2016: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 29% of which were caught in FU15. Irelands share in Sub-area 7 is the most valuable Nephrops TAC. In 2015 landings were worth approximately € 50,392,860 for Irish vessels
TAC2015: On average approximately 8,823 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014, 29% of which were caught in FU15. Irelands share in Sub-area 7 is the most valuable Nephrops TAC. In 2014 landings were worth approximately € 48,349,000 for Irish vessels
ICESAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2021 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 871 tonnes and 1053 tonnes, assuming recent discard rates. The entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule. To ensure that the stock in Functional Unit 14 is exploited sustainably, management should be implemented at the functional unit (FU) level. Note: This advice sheet is abbreviated due to the COVID-19 disruption. The previous advice issued for 2020 is attached as Annex 1.

FEASAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, and assuming zero discards, catches in 2021 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 2653 tonnes and 3290 tonnes. The entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule. To ensure that the stock in Functional Unit (FU) 16 is exploited sustainably, management should be implemented at the functional unit level. ICES have stated that the productivity of deep-water Nephrops stocks is generally lower and recruitment more sporadic than those in shelf waters. This makes these stocks more vulnerable to overexploitation. Therefore, ICES stated that the separate catch limit for FU 16 should remain in place.

The entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule. To ensure that the stock in functional unit (FU) 16 is exploited sustainably, management should be implemented at the functional unit level.

ICES state that the productivity of deep-water Nephrops stocks is generally lower and recruitment more sporadic than those in shelf waters. This makes these stocks more vulnerable to overexploitation. Therefore, ICES state that the separate catch limit for FU 16 should remain in place.
FEASAdvice2018:
ICES advises that when the MSY approach is applied, and assuming zero discards, catches in 2019 should be no more than 2,645 t. To ensure that the stock in functional unit (FU) 16 is exploited sustainably, management should be implemented at the functional unit level.

ICES state that the productivity of deep-water Nephrops stocks is generally lower and recruitment more sporadic than those in shelf waters. This makes these stocks more vulnerable to overexploitation. Given that the harvest rate for 2017 has increased, ICES state that the separate catch limit for FU 16 should remain in place.

SpeciesByDiv: Division 7.b  Functional Unit 17 (west of Ireland  Aran grounds)
Description:
Nephrops norvegicus is widely distributed on muddy substrates throughout the north-east Atlantic from Iceland in the north to Morocco in the south. SpeciesByDiv: Division 6.a  Functional Unit 11 (West of Scotland  North Minch)
Description:
Nephrops norvegicus is widely distributed on muddy substrates throughout the north-east Atlantic from Iceland in the north to Morocco in the south. Around Ireland they are found in depths from 20m to 600m but mainly at average depths of ~100 m on the shelf. They construct shallow burrows in muddy sediments which limits the distribution. Nephrops larvae hatch late spring/early summer. The females leave the burrows to hatch the eggs and mate. The eggs take about 4-8 weeks to develop into juveniles depending on water temperature. For the remainder of the year mature females then spend the majority of time in their burrows first to spawn the eggs and then incubate them. Male Nephrops are more active outside of the burrows foraging for food.

Unlike fish, there is no direct way to age Nephrops. Growth rates vary considerably in different areas. Mean size is negatively correlated with density of individuals. The maximum carapace length recorded for Nephrops is a male of 9.3 cm from the Porcupine Bank Irish sampling programme.
TAC2020: On average approximately 7,800 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019. FU20-21 accounted for the highest percentage of landings (27%) in 2019. In 2019 landings were worth more than 󌍩,400,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 8,300 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, 31% of which were caught in FU22.  In 2018 landings were worth more than &#8364 56,200,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, 31% of which were caught in FU22. In 2017 landings were worth more than € 56,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, 29% of which were caught in FU22. In 2016 landings were worth approximately € 60,000,000 making it Ireland's most valuable species for the first time.
TAC2016: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 29% of which were caught in FU15. Irelands share in Sub-area 7 is the most valuable Nephrops TAC. In 2015 landings were worth approximately € 50,392,860 for Irish vessels
TAC2015: On average approximately 8,823 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014, 29% of which were caught in FU15. Irelands share in Sub-area 7 is the most valuable Nephrops TAC. In 2014 landings were worth approximately € 48,349,000 for Irish vessels
ICESAdvice2020:
ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western Waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2021 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 3075 tonnes and 3953 tonnes, assuming recent discard rates. The entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.

To ensure that the stock in Functional Unit 11 is exploited sustainably, management should be implemented at the functional unit level.

To ensure that the stock in functional unit 13 is exploited sustainably, management should be implemented at the functional unit level.
ICESAdvice2019:
ICES advises that when the EU multiannual plan (MAP) for Western waters and adjacent waters is applied, catches in 2020 that correspond to the F ranges in the MAP are between 3924 and 5861  tonnes (3428-5227 tonnes for the Firth of Clyde and 496-634  tonnes for the Sound of Jura).  The entire range is considered precautionary when applying the ICES advice rule.

To ensure that Nephrops stocks are exploited sustainably, management of Nephrops should be implemented at the functional unit level. In this particular functional unit additional measures should be implemented to ensure that landings taken in each subarea (Firth of Clyde and Sound of Jura) are in line with the advice.

To ensure that Nephrops stocks are exploited sustainably, management of Nephrops in general should be implemented at the functional unit level. SpeciesByDivOrig: Norway lobster (Nephrops norvegicus) in Division 6.a  Functional Unit 13 (West of Scotland  the Firth of Clyde and Sound of Jura)
StockDev2020:
Norway lobster in Division 6.a, Functional Unit 13. Summary of the stock assessment. Catches (discard data only
available from 1990), harvest rate (sum of landings and dead discards in numbers, divided by stock abundance), and
stock abundance (underwater TV survey; 2*SD is approximate 95% confidence intervals). No abundance estimate is
available for the Sound of Jura in 1997–2000, 2004, 2008, or 2020. Harvest rates before 2006 may be unreliable
because of the underreporting of landings. Historical harvest rates were calculated using the total catch divided by the
stock abundance for the two subareas combined. The abundance is presented separately for the Firth of Clyde and for
the Sound of Jura.
StockDev2019: Norway lobster in Division 6.a, Functional Unit 13. Summary of the stock assessment. Catches (discard are data only available from 1990), harvest rate (sum of landings and dead discards in numbers, divided by total abundance), stock abundance (Underwater TV survey, millions; approximate 95% confidence intervals). Harvest rates before 2006 may be unreliable because of underreporting of landings. Historical harvest rates were calculated using the total catch divided by the total abundance for the two subareas combined. The orange lines represent the MSY B<sub>trigger</sub> for each of the subareas and the F<sub>MSY</sub> harvest rate for the Firth of Clyde. The abundance is presented separately for the Firth of Clyde and for the Sound of Jura.

SpeciesByDiv: Subarea 7, outside the Functional Units (southern Celtic Seas, southwest of Ireland)
Description:
Nephrops norvegicus is widely distributed on muddy substrates throughout the north-east Atlantic from Iceland in the north to Morocco in the south. Around Ireland they are found in depths from 20m to 600m but mainly at average depths of ~100 m on the shelf. They construct shallow burrows in muddy sediments which limits the distribution. Nephrops larvae hatch late spring/early summer. The females leave the burrows to hatch the eggs and mate. The eggs take about 4-8 weeks to develop into juveniles depending on water temperature. For the remainder of the year mature females then spend the majority of time in their burrows first to spawn the eggs and then incubate them. Male Nephrops are more active outside of the burrows foraging for food.

Unlike fish, there is no direct way to age Nephrops. Growth rates vary considerably in different areas. Mean size is negatively correlated with density of individuals. The maximum carapace length recorded for Nephrops is a male of 9.3 cm from the Porcupine Bank Irish sampling programme.
TAC2020: On average approximately 7,800 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2017 and 2019. FU20-21 accounted for the highest percentage of landings (27%) in 2019. In 2019 landings were worth more than 󌍩,400,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2019: On average approximately 8,300 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2016 and 2018, 31% of which were caught in FU22.  In 2018 landings were worth more than &#8364 56,200,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2018: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2015 and 2017, 31% of which were caught in FU22. In 2017 landings were worth more than € 56,000,000 for Irish vessels.
TAC2017: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2014 and 2016, 29% of which were caught in FU22. In 2016 landings were worth approximately € 60,000,000 making it Ireland's most valuable species for the first time.
TAC2016: On average approximately 8,640 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2013 and 2015, 29% of which were caught in FU15. Irelands share in Sub-area 7 is the most valuable Nephrops TAC. In 2015 landings were worth approximately € 50,392,860 for Irish vessels
TAC2015: On average approximately 8,823 tonnes of Nephrops were landed in Nephrops fisheries by Irish vessels between 2012 and 2014, 29% of which were caught in FU15. Irelands share in Sub-area 7 is the most valuable Nephrops TAC. In 2014 landings were worth approximately € 48,349,000 for Irish vessels

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 6.a  7.b  and 7.j (West of Scotland   West of Ireland  eastern part of southwest of Ireland)
Description: European sea bass is a marine member of the Order Perciformes and can be found distributed around the coasts of all countries in the north-west Atlantic region. It is a slow going species, living to over 25 years and reaching sexual maturation between ages 4 and 7. Juvenile sea bass, commonly found in inshore nurseries such as estuaries, begin shoaling as adolescents at 3 to 4 years of age. Adult sea bass typically spend warmer periods in shallow inshore waters where they feed opportunistically. At the onset of colder periods, some adults may migrate to offshore locations, presumably to spawn, while others have been found to reside in inshore waters, suggesting the potential for local spawning events and recruitment. Adult sea bass have been found to display high fidelity to inshore feeding areas with fish often present annually at the same locations.
TAC2020: Though distributed around the Irish coast, sea bass are primarily concentrated along the southern coast of divisions 7.j, 7.g. and 7.a. During colder periods, adult sea bass aggregate in shoals offshore to feed. Marine Institute research surveys have found a relatively clustered distribution of sea bass in the eastern Celtic Sea, particularly during the late autumn/early winter period.
TAC2019: Since 1990, there has been a ban on commercial fishing of sea bass by Irish vessels (Bass Conservation of Stocks Order, 1990). As a result, reported landings from Irish waters are relatively low. Recreational catches of sea bass are also strictly controlled. For 2019, a catch and release fishery is in operation between 1 January to 31 March and between 1 November and 31 December. A bag limit of one fish per angler per day with a minimum size limit of 42cm is in operation between 1 April and 31 October. This is subject to review at the end of 2019.
TAC2018: Since 1990, there has been a ban on commercial fishing of sea bass by Irish vessels. As a result, reported landings from Irish waters are relatively low. Recreational catches of sea bass are also strictly controlled with a bag limit of one fish per angler per day with a minimum size limit of 42cm.
ICESAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, commercial landings should be no more than 3 tonnes in each of the years 2021, 2022, and 2023. ICES cannot quantify total catches.
