SpeciesByDiv: North Atlantic
Description:
Albacore is a medium sized, pelagic, fish-eating, found offshore, surface and mid waters between 14 &deg and 21 &deg
Celsius. It is found from the Azores and Canaries north to Ireland, and westwards to the central USA. Separate
stocks occur in the south Atlantic and the Mediterranean. It is fast growing and recruits to the fishery by age 1,
with maximum age of 15 years. Maturation occurs at 5 years, corresponding to fork length of approximately
90 cm, and maximum size is 128 cm. Juveniles migrate north to SW Ireland in summer, to feed in surface waters.
Adults migrate, at depths from 50-150 m, to spawn off Venezuela, in the Gulf of Mexico and Sargasso Sea.
Spawning ensues from April to September.
TAC2020: Irish catches of Albacore Tuna in recent years have increased with a full quota uptake in 2019 (3,213 tonnes). The majority of catches was taken by pelagic pair trawl. Since 2017, the bulk of catches have been from ICES division 8 (Bay of Biscay) and landed into France and Spain. Previous to this, the majority of catch was taken in the Celtic Sea. In 2019, Irish landings were worth approximately €7 million.
TAC2019: Irish catches of Albacore Tuna in recent years have increased with a full quota uptake in 2018 (3,100 t). The majority of catches was taken by pelagic pair trawl. Since 2017, the bulk of catches have been from ICES division 8 (Bay of Biscay) and landed into France and Spain. Previous to this, the majority of catch was taken in the Celtic Sea. In 2018, Irish landings were worth approximately &#8364 8 million.
TAC2018: For the last three years, 2,400 to 2,500 t of albacore were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic pair-trawls. This roughly equals the Irish quota with 2017 having the highest catch. In 2015 and 2016 most landings were from the south-west of Ireland in 7.j,k,. France is the other dominant country fishing in this area. While limited landings from the Bay of Biscay are usual at the start of the season, this is where the bulk of the landings was coming from in 2017. In 2017, the price per kilogramme paid to Irish fishermen was about &#8364 2.60 and landings were worth approximately &#8364 6,469,000.
TAC2017: For the last three years, about 2400 tonnes of albacore were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic pair-trawls. This roughly equals the Irish quota although a slight decrease occurred during this period. Most landings were from the south-west of Ireland in 7.j,k, with occasional landings further to the south, usually at the start of the season. France is the other dominant country fishing in this area. In 2016, the price per kilogramme paid to Irish fishermen almost doubled to about &#8364 4 and landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,369,781 for Irish vessels
TAC2016: On average approximately 2,400 tonnes of albacore annually were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic pair-trawls between 2013 and 2015. This equals the annual quota. Most landings are from the south-west of Ireland in 7j,k, with occasional landings further to the south, usually at the start of the season. France is the other dominant country fishing in this area. In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 5,163,928 for Irish vessels.
ICESAdvice2017: The Standing Committee on Research and Statistics (SCRS) of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) is responsible for the assessment of the albacore tuna stocks and provides management advice to ICCAT, who subsequently set the TAC for the stock. The SCRS advice states catches in 2018 should not exceed 33,600 t if a harvest control rule is adopted, otherwise they should not exceed 28,000 t.
ICESAdvice2016: The Standing Committee on Research and Statistics (SCRS) of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) is responsible for the assessment of the albacore tuna stocks and provides management advice to ICCAT, who subsequently set the TAC for the stock. The SCRS advice states catches in 2017 should not exceed 28,000 t.
ICESAdvice2015:
ICCAT conducted an updated assessment in 2013. The SSB is estimated to be below SSBMSY (94% of SSBMSY), while F is estimated to be below F<sub>MSY</sub> (72% of F<sub>MSY</sub>). 

ICCAT projections at the current TAC level (28,000 t) indicate that the stock would rebuild by 2019 with 53% probability or by 2016 if the TAC is 20,000 t. FEAS notes that a probability of 53% implies that there is almost as great a likelihood of the target not being met. It is noted that ICCAT risk policy for bluefin tuna rebuilding is 60%.

In 2018, an external peer review was conducted and it confirmed that, overall, the MSE framework appears to be scientifically sound and robust to uncertainty.

In 2018, an external peer review was conducted and it confirmed that, overall, the MSE framework appears to be scientifically sound and robust to uncertainty.

SpeciesByDiv: East Atlantic and Mediterranean Sea
Description:
Bluefin tuna is the largest tuna, and one of the largest fish of all. It is a pelagic, fish-eating species, found from the
surface to depths of up to 1,000 m, and in temperatures from 3&deg to 30&deg Celsius. It is found throughout the Mediterranean and 
north Atlantic extending to the very cold waters off Norway. A separate stock occurs in the western north
Atlantic. It is fast growing and recruits to the fishery by age 1, with maximum age of at least 20 years. Maturation
occurs at 4 years, corresponding to fork length of approximately 115 cm, and maximum size is 400 cm. Juveniles
migrate north to SW Ireland in summer, to feed in surface waters. Adults migrate, at depths from 50-150 m, to
spawn off Venezuela, in the Gulf of Mexico and Sargasso Sea, and in the Mediterranean Sea. Spawning occurs
from May to June, but individuals may only spawn every 2-3 years. Bluefin tuna are highly opportunistic predators that feed primarily on schooling fish. While they do eat pelagic shoaling fish such as herring and mackerel, there is no evidence that they specifically target them.
TAC2020: Ireland has no directed fishery for Bluefin Tuna. In 2019, 6.4 tonnes of Bluefin tuna were caught and landed by Irish vessels as bycatch (mainly in the albacore fishery) for which there is a minor quota. In 2019 the value of the catch of Bluefin tuna was worth approximately €32,000.
TAC2019: Ireland has no directed fishery for Bluefin Tuna. In 2018, 16.6 t of Bluefin tuna were caught and landed by Irish vessels as bycatch (mainly in the albacore fishery) for which there is a minor quota. The annual value of catches in recent years (with the exception of 2016) is approximately &#8364 100,000.
TAC2018: In 2017, 16.1 t of Bluefin tuna were caught and landed by Irish vessels. This is about half that of 2016 and back to levels observed in previous years. Fish were bycaught in the albacore tuna fishery using mainly pelagic trawls. Ireland cannot target bluefin tuna, but can land them using the bycatch quota available to countries other than France, Spain and Portugal. Landings of bluefin tuna were worth approximately &#8364 98,000 in 2017, back to the level observed before 2016.
TAC2017: In 2016, about 34 tonnes of bluefin tuna were caught and landed by Irish vessels. This is about twice as much as in years 2014 and 2016. Fish were bycaught in the albacore tuna fishery using mainly pelagic trawls. Ireland cannot target bluefin tuna, but can land them using the bycatch quota available to countries other than France, Spain and Portugal. Landings of bluefin tuna were worth approximately &#8364 263,000 in 2016, more than twice their worth the previous few years.
TAC2016: On average approximately 15 tonnes of bluefin tuna annually were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic trawls between 2013 and 2015. These were bycaught in the albacore tuna fishery. Ireland cannot target bluefin tuna, but can land them using the bycatch quota available to countries other than France, Spain and Portugal. Landings of bluefin tuna are worth approximately &#8364 100,000 annually
ICESAdvice2017: The Standing Committee on Research and Statistics (SCRS) of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) is responsible for the assessment of the Bluefin tuna stocks and provides management advice to ICCAT, who subsequently set the TAC for the stock. The SCRS advises that the catches be increased using a gradual stepwise approach to 36,000 t in 2020. The continuation of the stepped increases should be reviewed annually
ICESAdvice2016: The Standing Committee on Research and Statistics (SCRS) of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) is responsible for the assessment of the Bluefin tuna stocks and provides management advice to ICCAT, who subsequently set the TAC for the stock. The SCRS advice states catches in 2017 should not exceed 23,155 t.
ICESAdvice2015:
FEAS notes that, based on ICCAT projections, the TACs agreed for 2015-2017 are consistent with the goal of achieving F<sub>MSY</sub> and BMSY through 2022 with greater than 60% probability. Therefore FEAS advises that the TAC in 2016 should be no more than 18,911 t. 

In 2014 ICCAT carried out an updated assessment. In 2015 ICCAT examined new biological and catch information. While evaluations all continue to show that there has been a recent increase in SSB, the magnitude and rate of the increase remain highly uncertain.  

In 2014 ICCAT agreed a 20% annual increase in TAC from 2015- 2017.  In 2015 SCRS advises that these TACs are not expected to undermine the success of the rebuilding plan and are consistent with the goal of achieving F<sub>MSY</sub> and BMSY through 2022 with at least 60% probability. A new assessment will take place in 2016.   


Ireland has no target fisheries and by-catches in pelagic fisheries are subject to an unallocated bycatch quota for EU vessels (32.97 t in 2015). This by-catch allowance may be very restrictive as the stock rebuilds. FEAS advises that when the stock can be shown to have rebuilt with at least 60% probability, the rebuilding measures should be replaced with a long term management strategy. Such a strategy should contain adequate provision for unavoidable by-catch in non-target fisheries.

This stock has been subject to the landing obligation since 1 January 2015. There is no proposed quota uplift as ICCAT considers discards to be negligible.

A rebuilding plan has been in place for this stock since 2006.

FEASAdvice2020:
The 2020 assessment did not provide reliable information on which to base TAC advice for 2021. However, based on stock size indices, there is no clear evidence of changes in stock biomass from 2017 to 2020 to support changing the current TAC (Rec. 19-04) for 2021 and 2022. The corresponding TAC is 36,000 t. 
The Committee recommends extending the MSE process for another year with a goal of completing the MSE process in time for the 2022 Commission meeting to provide TAC advice for 2023-2025.
FEASAdvice2019:
The 2017 advice included a recommendation to evaluate indices annually to advise on the continuation of the stepped increase. In 2019 the fishery indicators did not indicate a reason to alter current management advice. Consequently, the Committee is of the view that the stepped increase for 2020 from Rec. 18-02 can be maintained. The corresponding TAC is 36,000 t. 
The Committee recommends extending the MSE process for another year with a goal of completing the MSE process in time for the 2021 Commission meeting to provide TAC advice for 2022-2024.
FEASAdvice2018:
The 2017 advice included a recommendation to evaluate indices annually to advise on the continuation of the stepped increase. The indices, which have been updated up to 2017, did not clearly indicate any change in the stock abundance. Consequently, the Committee is of the view that the stepped increase from Rec 17-07 and recommended for 2019 is compatible with the rebuilding plan and can be maintained. The corresponding TAC is 32,240 t.

Given the abundance increase reported in 2017 assessment, the Committee advises that the Commission should consider moving from the current rebuilding plan to a management plan, while not weakening the current monitoring and control measures. The indices that have been updated through 2017 provided no clear indication to deviate from this advice.

SpeciesByDiv: Sub-area 6 and Divisions 7.a-c and f-k
Description: Sprat is a pelagic schooling fish usually found inshore, with juveniles sometimes found in estuaries. The species is widely distributed from Morocco to the South of Norway and four different stocks are identified in European waters. Although work is on going to identify the number of stocks in the Celtic Seas Ecoregion, i.e. ICES Divisions 6 and 7 (excluding 7.d & 7.e), ICES has considered that sprat in these areas are part of one stock since 2011. Sprat perform seasonal migrations between winter-feeding and summer spawning grounds as well as diel vertical migrations. Sprat reach a total length of 18 cm, size-at-maturity has been estimated at 10.1 cm and is highly variable between areas. Spawning occurs in shallow waters (10-20 m) and egg production ranges 6,000-14,000. There is currently no evidence of spawning site fidelity (homing). European sprat is an important species in the trophic web as it links between zooplankton and top predators (fish and marine mammals).
TAC2020: The annual catch of sprat is highly variable. On average, 7,000 tonnes of European sprat were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using primarily pelagic trawls between 2017 and 2019. Catches primarily come from the southwest and northwest of Ireland and the Irish Sea. In 2019 sprat catches increased significantly to 13,000 tonnes (worth approximately €3.5 million) that were caught primarily in 7.j and to a lesser extent in 6.a and 7.a.
TAC2019: The annual catch of sprat is highly variable. On average, 4,490 t of European sprat were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using primarily pelagic trawls between 2016 and 2018. Catches primarily come from the southwest and northwest of Ireland and the Irish sea. From 2015 to 2018, value of Irish landings decreased from &#8364 2,637,000 to &#8364 961,000 following a decrease in catches.
TAC2018: On average, 6,118 t of European sprat were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using primarily pelagic trawls between 2015 and 2017. The annual catch is highly variable, a two-fold decrease was observed between 2015 (9,332 t) and 2016 (4,763 t) and catch remained stable in 2017 (4,260 t). Value followed the same trend as catch decreasing from &#8364 2,097,000 to &#8364 881,000 over the years 2015-2017. Sprat appears to be a secondary target species for the Irish fleet, i.e. vessels target it when their primary target is not accessible.

SpeciesByDiv: Sub-areas 1-14
Description: Spurdog are widely distributed throughout the North-East Atlantic. One stock is considered in the area.
TAC2020: The TAC is zero. However a (bycatch) TAC of 270 tonnes is available for countries that have a specific spurdog avoidance bycatch programme. Ireland was allocated a quota of 53 t under this TAC.
ICESAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, there should be no targeted fisheries on this stock in 2021 and 2022.
ICESAdvice2018:
ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, there should be no targeted fisheries on this stock in 2019 and 2020. Landing of bycatch should be part of a management plan, including close monitoring of the stock and fisheries.

Based on medium-term projections, annual catches at the recent assumed level (2468 tonnes) would allow the stock to increase at a rate close to that estimated with zero catches; therefore ICES considers that bycatch should not exceed that level.
ICESAdvice2017:
In 2016 ICES advised that when the precautionary approach is applied, there
should be no targeted fisheries on this stock in 2017 and 2018. Based on
medium-term projections, annual catches at the recent assumed level
(2,468 t) would allow the stock to increase at a rate close to that estimated
with zero catches. Any possible provision for the landing of bycatch should be
part of a management plan, including close monitoring of the stock and
fisheries.

FEASAdvice2020: ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, there should be no targeted fisheries on this stock in 2021 and 2022.
FEASAdvice2019:
ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, there should be no targeted fisheries on this stock in 2019 and 2020. Landing of bycatch should be part of a management plan, including close monitoring of the stock and fisheries. 

Based on medium-term projections, annual catches at the recent assumed level (2,468 t) would allow the stock to increase at a rate close to that estimated with zero catches; therefore ICES considers that bycatch should not exceed that level.

In a response to the EC on the removal of TACs for certain stocks ICES advises that removing the EU TAC for spurdog may generate a high risk of the stocks being exploited unsustainably.
FEASAdvice2018:
ICES advises that when the precautionary approach is applied, there should be no targeted fisheries on this stock in 2019 and 2020. Landing of bycatch should be part of a management plan, including close monitoring of the stock and fisheries.

Based on medium-term projections, annual catches at the recent assumed level (2,468 t) would allow the stock to increase at a rate close to that estimated with zero catches; therefore ICES considers that bycatch should not exceed that level.

In a response to the EC on the removal of TACs for certain stocks ICES advises that removing the EU TAC for spurdog may generate a high risk of the stocks being exploited unsustainably.
